topics.topic_name: Enviromental Science physical and chemical properties of the surface water
topics.topic_html:
Physical and Chemical Properties of the Surface Water Collected from Various Sites to Measure of the Organic Carbon

Abstract :

The southern coastal area of Bangladesh is significant for its remarkable hydrogeological features and aquifer systems. Barisal University attempted to examine and evaluate the quality of its groundwater. The purpose of this study was to analyse the current state of physicochemical qualities in five different water reservoirs :

  • Kirtonkhola River
  • London Bridge Lake
  • Pond (1) in front of the VC gate
  • Pond (2) in front of the library
  • Pond 3 in front of the Girls' Dormitory

This study measured surface water pH, TDS, EC, DO, and BOD as well as water physicochemical measurements to determine the amount of water carbon in five fresh water reservoirs on and around the Barishal University campus.

Introduction

Surface water, a crucial natural resource, is essential for various human activities, including drinking, irrigation, and industrial processes. However, anthropogenic activities and natural processes can significantly impact the physicochemical properties of surface water, affecting its quality and suitability for different uses. This study aims to evaluate the physicochemical properties of surface water samples collected from five distinct sites in University of Barishal

Physicochemical parameters, such as pH, temperature, conductivity, turbidity, total dissolved solids (TDS), and dissolved oxygen (DO), provide valuable insights into the overall water quality. Deviations from established standards can indicate
pollution or environmental degradation. By analysing these parameters, this study seeks to assess the current state of the surface water bodies and identify potential sources of contamination

The findings of this research will contribute to a better understanding of the environmental conditions in the study area and inform decision-making regarding water resource management, pollution control, and public health.

Study Sites :

This study was conducted on August 18th to 23rd 2024 on the University of Barishal's five aquatic sites as seen in figure-02 & 03. The east-side parking lots were built for water to drain into the ditches that run along the backside of the campus. These ditches then drain into the duck pond located south of the parking lot. There were five stations along the drainage ditches and the pond where test samples were taken in order to determine water quality

Collections of Samples :

To gather samples, prewashed 1L plastic bottles were used. The bottles were washed again with sample water. The bottles were tightly closed before being plunged in lakes in fig-(02,03,04) and ponds to a depth of 0.5 m. Bottles were opened in the water to collect samples, then closed again. The samples were obtained from five distinct locations, with replicates of each sampling site.

Physicochemical Parameters :
  • Samples were taken to determine the elemental qualities of the lake and pond water
  • The parameters measured and analysed were pH and total dissolved solids
  • The water temperature was measured with a Centigrade thermometer
  • The colour of water was observed to have an effect on eye distinguishing
  • Secchi discs were used to record the transparency
  • After transporting the samples to the MS laboratory of the Department of Soil and Environmental Sciences at the University of Barishal, the remaining properties were analysed
  • The electric conductivity and pH of the water were measured using a Pocket multipara meter (HANNA Instruments, model DiST4, HI98304)
  • A portable dissolved oxygen meter (DO meter, Model DO30) was used to measure the water's dissolved oxygen

PH

Principle :
  • pH is a measure of acidity and alkenity of the water
  • A pH of seven is neutral , while values below 7 are acidic and above are alkaline
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that the pH of drinking water should be between 6.5 and 8.5 , this range is considered safe and acceptable for human consumption
Apparatus :
  • Beaker 100 ml
  • Glass electrode pH meter( Model: HI700663)
  • Stirring rods
  • Sample water
Procedure :
  • 10 ml sample was taken into a 100 ml Baker
  • The pH meter (Model: HI700663) was switched on and adjusted with the sample
  • The electrode was placed into the sample and read the pH value
  • Result among the group 7.9 - 7.44 - 7.44-7.21-7.85
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

The pH of the sampling locations ranged between 7.95 and 8.15 on average. The greatest pH value was 7.90, while the minimum was 7.21. Sewage or terrestrial run-off from surrounding abodes containing carbonates and bicarbonates may be responsible for the highest pH readings in sample sites. Typically, alkaline water aids in the proliferation of phytoplankton in confined water bodies. Research has revealed that pH ranges of 7-8 are suitable for fish culture and the majority of aquatic species. The pH in most raw water sources ranges between 6.5 and 8.5 (1416). The pH of these water reservoirs imply the prospect of suitable aquaculture, and it was previously noted that this city has phytoplankton richness in its freshwater bodies.

TDS

Principle :
  • The principle behind using an EC meter to determine TDS is that the dissolved salts and minerals in water contribute to it’s electrical conductivity.
  • The conversion factor usually ranges from 0.5 to 0.7, depending on the specific ionic composition of the water
Apparatus :
  • Beaker 100 ml
  • Sample water
  • EC meter (JENCO- EC330)
Procedure :
  • 10 ml sample was taken into a 100 ml beaker
  • The EC meter (JENCO- EC330) was switched on and adjusted with the sample
  • The electrode was placed into the sample and read the TDS value
  • Result among the group : 110-95-130-75-65
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

Total dissolved solids in aquatic environments primarily indicate the inorganic pollution load of the water system, whereas electrical conductivity measures the concentration of ions in water.The study area had the highest levels of TDS (130 mg/l) and EC (135 μS/cm) and the lowest values of TDS (65 mg/l) and EC (260 μS/cm).
As we can see from the TDS readings, all of the samples' test results were around (65-130)ppm, which is not ideal based on WHO recommendations of (150-250)ppm. Fortunately none of the samples' test results came close to the standard, hence the TDS of all the samples is extremely low. The addition of organic compounds from degraded aquatic creatures may be responsible for the total dissolved solids concentration. As TDS values vary, so may the algae diversity found in these reservoirs.

EC

Principle :
  • Measures water's ability to conduct an electric current, which is affected by the presence of dissolved salts and minerals. Units are generally micro Siemens per centimetre (µS/cm)
  • Higher EC values imply increased dissolved ion concentrations, which can be used to evaluate water quality and detect pollution levels
Apparatus :
  • Beaker 100 ml
  • Sample water
  • EC meter (JENCO- EC330)
Procedure :
  • 10 ml sample was taken into a 100 ml beaker
  • The EC meter (JENCO- EC330) was switched on and adjusted with the sample
  • The electrode was placed into the sample and read the TDS value
  • Result among the group : 220-190-260-145-135
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

London Bridge Lake and Kirtonkhola River have low electric conductivity (EC) values of 145 μS/cm and 135 μS/cm, indicating good water quality. BU Pond -1 and BU Pond-2 had higher electric conductivity (EC) due to water pollution, but BU Pond-3 had the highest EC at 260 μS/cm, indicating the most polluted water among the sites

DO

Principle :
  • The amount of oxygen dissolved in water that is required for aquatic life is
    referred to as dissolved oxygen. The units are milligrams per litre (mg/L)
  • The reaction produces an electrical current that is proportional to the concentration of oxygen in the water
Apparatus :
  • Beaker 100 ml
  • Sample water
  • DO meter (Model HQ30D)
Procedure :
  • 10 ml sample was taken into a 100 ml beaker
  • The DO meter (Model: HQ30D) was switched on and adjusted with the sample
  • The electrode was placed into the sample and read the DO value.
  • Result among the group : 7.81-6.81-6.47-7.96-8.74
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

DO readings represent the physical and biological processes that occur in the water. It also reveals the level of contamination in water bodies. The lowest DO level was measured (6.47 mg/l) for all sites.

WHO recommends measuring :
  • DO levels in water for irrigation (4.5-8 ppm)
  • DO levels in fisheries (5 ppm or below)
  • DO levels in drinking (6 ppm)

So, based on our sample collection, all of our DO levels were 6.47 ppm, which is close to the drinking water guideline.As a result, the pond is not also ideal for fish culture. So Professor recommended that before approaching any fish or other aquatic organisms in this pond, it is necessary to first maintain the standard DO level

BOD

Principle :
  • A measure of the quantity of oxygen needed to breakdown organic materials in water. The units are milligrams per litre (mg/L)
  • Monitoring BOD levels contributes to the protection of aquatic ecosystems and the prevention of pollution-related harm
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION of pH :

In wastewater treatment plants, BOD is a key measure of treatment efficiency. The purpose is to reduce the BOD levels to acceptable limits before dumping treated effluent into receiving waterways.
After examining all the samples for 5 days at 20°C, the parameters (BOD, TDS, pH, EC, and DO) were determined. If we look at the BOD measurements, we can see that all of the groups had BOD levels between 2 and 3, and we know from the WHO standard chart that BOD (1-2) ppm is extremely good and (3-5) ppm is somewhat clean.
BOD levels range between 2.10 and 3.60 mg/L.BOD indicates how much oxygen bacteria will require while digesting organic materials in water. Higher BOD levels, as seen in the Kirtonkhola River, indicate higher amounts of organic pollution.

Here's a table that organizes the provided data:

SI Number SAMPLE Site D1 (mg/l) D2 (mg/l) BOD (D1-D2)
G-1 VC Gate 10.13 7.81 2.32
G-2 VC Near library 10.41 6.81 3.60
G-3 VC Girls' Dormitory 9.92 6.47 3.18
G-4 VC Bridge 10.55 7.96 2.59
G-5 VC Lake 10.84 8.74 2.10
- River - - - -

D1 refers to the DO level after 5 days of measurement, while D2 relates to the water's initial BOD

Chemical Bond

keywords

stable molecule,electrostatic attraction,valence shell,in excess,stable electron-octet,electron pair,nuclei,repel,attract,unshared electron,share pair,donor,acceptor,electronegative

Definition
  • Chemical Bond : A chemical bond is defined as a force that acts between two or more atoms to hold them together as a stable molecule

  1. Ionic Bond: A chemical bond formed through the electrostatic attraction between positively and negatively charged ions.

    Ionic or Electrovalent compound:A compound containing ionic bond referted to ionic compound

  2. Covalent Bond: A chemical bond where two atoms share one or more pairs of electrons.(GN.Lewis)

  3. Coordinate Covalent Bond: A covalent bond where both shared electrons come from the same atom.

  4. Polar Bond: A covalent bond with unequal sharing of electrons due to differences in electronegativity between atoms and bounded atom acquire a partial and positive and negative charge,is called a polar covalent bond

    Non-Polar Bond: A non-polar covalent bond is a chemical bond where electrons are shared equally between two identical atoms or atoms with similar electronegativities.

  5. Hydrogen Bond: A weak bond between a hydrogen atom covalently bonded to an electronegative atom and another electronegative atom.

Type of chemical bond :
  • Ionic or Electrovalent bond
  • Covalent bond
  • Coordinate covalent bond
Ionic Bond vs Covalent Bond
Ionic
Covalent
Formed by transfer of electron from a metal to non-metal atom
Formed by sharing of electrons between non-metal atoms
Consists of electrostatic force between positive and negative ions
Consists of shared pair of electrons between atom
Non-rigid and non-directional;can not cause isomerism
Rigid and directional;cause stereoisomerism
Ionic Compound vs Covalent Compound
Ionic Compound
Covalent Compound
Solids at room temperature
Gases.Liquids or soft solids
Hight melting and boiling points
Low melting and boiling points
Hard and brittle
Soft,much readilty broken
Soluble in water but insoluble in organic solvents
Insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents
Conductors of electricity
Non-conductors of electricity
Undergo ionic reaction which are fast
Undergo molecular reactions which are slow
Some Details :
  • In covalent bond the nuclei of two atoms are pulled towards each other by the attraction of the shared electron pair.At the same time the neclei of two atoms also repel each other.It is the net attarctive force between the shared electron and the nuclei that holds the atoms together.
  • In polar bond as the electron shared unequally this cause making one end of the bond partially positive and other partially negative

Ionic Bond > Covalent Bond > Polar Covalent Bond > Non-Polar Covalent Bond > Hydrogen Bond

Lecture 3 (sorces of alkanes)

  • A hydrocarbon is a compound composed only of carbon and hydrogen
  • Saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes and cycloalkanes) contain only C-C single bonds
  • Alkanes have the general formula CnH2n+2

The three major sources of alkanes throughout the world are the fossil fuels. The fossil fuels are natural gas, petroleum, and coal.

Natural Gas

Natural Gas consists of approximately

  • 90%–95% methane
  • 5%–10% ethane
  • and a mixture of other relatively low-boiling alkanes, chiefly propane, butane, and 2-methylpropane

Cracking

Cracking is a process whereby a saturated hydrocarbon is converted into an unsaturated hydrocarbon plus H2

CH3CH3(800-900)∘→CH2=CH2+H2

In this example saturated hydrocarbon methane converted into unsaturated hydrocarbon ethane or ethylene

Petroleum

Petroleum is a thick, viscous, liquid mixture of thousands of compounds, most of them hydrocarbons, formed from the decomposition of marine plants and animals

Important of Petroleum

Petroleum and petroleum-derived products fuel automobiles, aircraft, and trains. They provide most of the greases and lubricants required for the machinery of our highly industrialized society.
Furthermore, petroleum, along with natural gas, provides nearly 90% of the organic raw materials for the synthesis and manufacture of synthetic fibers, plastics, detergents, drugs, dyes, and a multitude of other products.

Petroleum Refining
  • The fundamental separation process in refining petroleum is fractional distillation
  • Practically all crude petroleum that enters a refinery goes to distillation units, where it is heated to temperatures as high as 370 to 425°C and separated into fractions
  • Each fraction contains a mixture of hydrocarbons that boils within a particular range
Petroleum

Coal

Synthesis Gas

Synthesis Gas is a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen in varying proportion depending on the means by which it is manufactured

  • Synthesis gas is prepared by passing steam over hot coal
    C+H2O→CO+H2
  • It is also prepared by partial oxidation of methane with oxygen
    CH4+12O2→CO+2H2
